author: R.S.N. MURALI
title: Public fountain not a place to play
text:
by r.s.n. murali The water fountain at Dataran 1Malaysia in Klebang is a popular hangout among families in Malacca. – filepic 
MALACCA: Enforcement officers from the Malacca Historic City Council (MBMB) will be placed at the water fountain in Dataran 1Malaysia, Klebang to ensure children do not play there. 
State Housing, Local Government and Environment Committee chairman Datuk Ismail Othman said the fountain was a decorative feature and not a swimming pool. 
“Recent reports that the water was contaminated with rotavirus and had infected children would not have happened if the fountain had not been used a swimming pool by irresponsible people,” he said after opening the Hang Tuah Jaya Municipal Council’s (MPHTJ) Community Awards event at Bayou Lagoon Park Resort. 
Bayou Lagoon Park Resort managing director Datuk Marco Seow (left) receiving a trophy and certificate from Ismail (right) during the Community Awards 2016. Looking on is MPHTJ president Datuk Murad Husin. 
Nevertheless, Ismail said water samples from the fountain have been sent to the Health Ministry for a second laboratory test. 
“The first test proved that the water was not contaminated but we are doing it a second time following reports of a rotavirus outbreak,” he said, adding that the result of the second test would be known in a week. 
Ismail said there was no truth to reports that a rotavirus outbreak had caused several children to seek treatment in Hospital Malacca. 
He said a signboard prohibiting the public from bathing in the fountain will also be erected while the splash mechanism in the fountain has been discontinued. 
A notice had earlier been put up by the local authority advising the public against bathing at the site. 
Earlier, some 59 agencies, companies and hotels received awards in various categories, including best taxpayer, highest contributor, active media, best stall and low carbon community at the event. 
Mamee Double Decker and Bayou Lagoon Park were among the recipients for highest tax contributors to the council. 
The Star’s Malacca Bureau also won an award in the active media category.
